title: Alden 44
text:
The Alden 44 is an American <a href="sailboat">sailboat</a> that was designed by <a href="Alden%20Associates">Alden Associates</a> and <a href="Niels%20Helleberg">Niels Helleberg</a> as an <a href="International%20Offshore%20Rule">International Offshore Rule</a> <a href="Sailing%20%28sport%29">racer</a> and first built in 1976.
Production.
The design was built by <a href="Tillotson%20Pearson">Tillotson Pearson</a> in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> for <a href="Alden%20Yachts">Alden Yachts</a>, but it is now out of production.
Design.
The Alden 44 is a recreational <a href="keelboat">keelboat</a>, built predominantly of <a href="fiberglass">fiberglass</a>, with wood trim. It has a <a href="raked%20stem">raked stem</a>, a raised counter <a href="reverse%20transom">reverse transom</a>, a <a href="skeg">skeg</a>-mounted <a href="rudder">rudder</a> controlled by a <a href="Ship%27s%20wheel">wheel</a>, <a href="aluminum">aluminum</a> spars and a fixed stub fin <a href="keel">keel</a>, with a retractable <a href="centerboard">centerboard</a>. It displaces and carries of lead ballast.
The boat has a variety of possible interior layouts, but typical is sleeping accommodation for seven people, with a double "V"-berth in the bow cabin, an "L"-shaped settee, with a drop-leaf table and a straight settee, plus a pilot berth in the main cabin and an aft cabin with two berths. The aft cabin has its own <a href="companionway">companionway</a> ladder from the cockpit. The <a href="Galley%20%28kitchen%29">galley</a> is located on the starboard side beside the forward companionway ladder with the double sink located underneath the steps. The galley is equipped with a <a href="propane">propane</a>-fired three-burner stove and oven as well as a refrigerator and a freezer. The large <a href="Head%20%28watercraft%29">head</a> is located just forward of the aft cabin on the port side, with access from the aft cabin and the main cabin. It includes a shower. Main cabin trim is of <a href="Fraxinus">ash</a> wood.
Ventilation is provided by five translucent hatches and seven opening ports.
For sailing the design is equipped with two <a href="winch">winch</a>es for the main <a href="halyard">halyard</a>, two for the <a href="genoa%20%28sail%29">genoa</a> halyard, two for the <a href="spinnaker">spinnaker</a> halyard and two for the <a href="staysail">staysail</a> halyard, two primary and two secondary winches for the genoa <a href="sheet%20%28sailing%29">sheets</a>, two for the staysail sheets, two for the <a href="mainsheet">mainsheet</a>, two for the spinnaker sheets and one for the <a href="outhaul">outhaul</a>. The majority of the installed winches are self-tailing. The design also has a <a href="topping%20lift">topping lift</a>.
Operational history.
In a 1994 review Richard Sherwood wrote, "The Alden [44] is designed for IOR competition but has many cruising amenities. The hull is moderate displacement. She is claimed to be fast, dry, stiff, and close-winded."
Reviewer Steve Knauth described the design in 2014, in "Soundings", "the 44 was different from the old schooners, with its cutter rig, keel/centerboard and skeg-hung rudder. Yet it was perfectly in the Alden tradition of racing/cruising yachts. The boat could handle a crew of seven — enough for a Bermuda Race — and its competitive qualities were soon apparent. The Alden 44 quickly established a reputation for bluewater racing and passagemaking." He concludes that it "remains one of the prettiest sailboats you'll see in any harbor."
